Description: The time gap between the start of a flow anomaly and the first device activation in the same zone measures anomaly-to-alert reaction time.
Short rationale: Mostly about system responsiveness; weak indirect signal of whether humans are slow/fast to react.

Description: Flow anomalies that begin and end with no device activations in their window represent unmitigated anomalies where the system detected unusual flow but never acted.
Short rationale: Flags detected-but-unhandled events; risk and configuration, not behavior.

Description: For anomalies where a shutoff valve or similar device activates, a rapid decline or termination of the anomaly afterward indicates successful mitigation.
Short rationale: Measures mitigation quality after activation; device performance only.

Description: Flow anomalies that recur with similar shape and magnitude and consistently do not trigger device activations represent patterns deemed benign by current rules.
Short rationale: Encodes which patterns rules ignore; reflects policy/config, not people.

Description: Device activations that occur in time windows without any corresponding flow anomaly indicate alerts triggered by other signals, noise, or misconfiguration.
Short rationale: Shows alerts without anomalies; about noise/misconfig, not users.

Description: Comparing which flow anomalies do trigger activations versus those that do not reveals an implicit flow threshold that drives device actions.
Short rationale: Extracts implicit thresholds from history; configuration signal.

Inference: Distinguishing genuine anomaly response from scheduled tests
Description: Device activations that follow no anomaly and occur at regular intervals can be classified as scheduled system tests rather than responses to real anomalies.
Short rationale: Regular test patterns reveal maintenance schedules/ops habits at property level.

Description: Very short anomaly-to-activation intervals point to automated actions, while longer and more variable intervals indicate manual user-triggered responses.
Short rationale: Directly separates automatic vs manual responses, exposing when humans act and how quickly.

Inference: Measuring anomaly duration reduction due to devices
Description: Comparing anomaly durations with device activations to those without shows how much devices shorten abnormal flow events.
Short rationale: Compares durations with/without devices; effectiveness metric only.

Description: Zones with frequent or severe flow anomalies but few or slow device activations are under-responsive and need additional devices or faster rules.
Short rationale: Highlights zones where anomalies get little response; property risk map, mild behavior/policy implication.

Description: Zones where many device activations occur in response to small, short-lived anomalies are likely over-instrumented or have overly aggressive triggers.
Short rationale: Indicates overly aggressive triggering; config/design issue.

Description: For large anomalies where multiple devices activate, anomalies that end quickly afterward demonstrate the benefit of coordinated multi-device responses.
Short rationale: Shows benefit of coordinating devices; purely technical.

Description: When a large anomaly triggers an initial device but only terminates after a second escalation activation, escalation stages are shown to be important for full mitigation.
Short rationale: Evaluates escalation stages; control strategy, not personal info.

Inference: Detection of benign but noisy flow conditions
Description: Repeated anomalies that always lead to activations but never relate to real issues suggest noisy flow conditions that should be deprioritized or filtered.
Short rationale: Tags noisy conditions; helps rule tuning, not user profiling.

Description: If anomalies at night tend to have longer anomaly-to-activation times than those during working hours, response speed is time-of-day dependent.
Short rationale: Night vs daytime response speeds reflect operational/attention patterns, but only weakly tie to identity.

Inference: Using anomaly recurrence after resolution to detect incomplete fixes
Description: When an anomaly ends after device activation but similar anomalies recur shortly afterward, the underlying issue was not properly fixed.
Short rationale: Indicates repair quality; maintenance outcome.

Inference: Inferring device malfunction from non-effect on anomalies
Description: If a device frequently activates during anomalies but anomaly magnitude and duration remain similar to events without that device, the device may be ineffective or malfunctioning.
Short rationale: Detects malfunctioning devices; technical state only.

Description: Anomalies that always trigger activations and are externally classified as serious become canonical critical patterns, distinct from anomalies that seldom require action.
Short rationale: Labels certain anomalies as “critical”; policy/engineering info.

Inference: Separating upstream vs. downstream anomaly handling
Description: If anomalies on an upstream main line consistently trigger main shutoff activations while branch-level anomalies trigger local devices, patterns confirm an intended upstream/downstream policy.
Short rationale: Confirms intended control policy by line level; structural.

Inference: Learning anomaly patterns that safely self-resolve
Description: Flow anomalies that reliably self-resolve without any device activation and cause no damage can be tagged as self-resolving anomalies to avoid unnecessary actions.
Short rationale: Marks self-resolving anomalies; helps avoid overreaction, not behavioral.

Inference: Detecting configuration drift or rule changes
Description: If anomalies of a given magnitude historically always led to activations but later similar anomalies do not, the anomaly–activation relationship shows configuration changes or rule drift.
Short rationale: Shows when rules/config change over time; admin/system-level.

Inference: Estimating miss cost of unhandled anomalies
Description: For anomalies without device activation that are later associated with damage or leaks, these events define the cost of not acting on that anomaly type.
Short rationale: Quantifies damage from unhandled events; risk assessment.

Inference: Mapping device coverage to anomaly types
Description: Different anomaly shapes that trigger different subsets of devices reveal how well each device type covers different anomaly types.
Short rationale: Links devices to anomaly types they handle; coverage map.

Inference: Classifying nuisance anomalies from response history
Description: Anomaly types that repeatedly generate device activations but consistently correspond to no real issue can be tagged as nuisance anomalies and deprioritized.
Short rationale: Tags nuisance patterns; again about tuning, not people.

Inference: Joint anomaly–activation fingerprints for incident classification
Description: For each incident, the combination of anomaly shape, which devices activated, and how quickly they did so forms a fingerprint for classifying incidents into specific categories.
Short rationale: Rich fingerprints could, when joined with other data, support finer-grained incident and behavior profiling, but still mainly technical.
